diagrams.description: Signal Processing evolved from analog circuit theory to sophisticated digital algorithms transforming communication and computation. Early signal processing used analog filters and amplifiers (1920s-1930s) for telecommunications. Shannon's information theory (1948) established theoretical foundations for signal transmission and capacity. The sampling theorem by Nyquist-Shannon formalized analog-to-digital conversion requirements. Digital computers enabled numerical signal processing in the 1950s-1960s. The Fast Fourier Transform algorithm by Cooley and Tukey (1965) revolutionized frequency analysis making it computationally practical. Digital signal processors emerged in the 1970s as specialized hardware for real-time processing. The discrete cosine transform (1974) enabled JPEG image compression. Wavelet theory developed in the 1980s providing multi-resolution time-frequency analysis. MPEG audio/video compression standards (1990s) enabled digital media distribution. Adaptive filtering and blind source separation advanced in the 1990s. Compressed sensing theory (2004) enabled signal reconstruction from sparse measurements. Software-defined radio emerged allowing flexible reconfigurable systems. Deep learning revolutionized signal processing (2010s+) for speech recognition, image classification, and more. Today's signal processing integrates AI, edge computing for real-time processing, 5G communications, and quantum signal processing explorations.
